s.text: The NYT , in the wake of the Karla Faye Tucker execution, ran in Sunday's "Week in Review" a brutally reported and mug-shot illustrated piece by Sam Howe Verhovek on some of the other women waiting on America's Death Rows.
The Times states that likely U.S. strike targets include Republican Guard bases, military command centers and suspected weapons factories and stockpiles.

Sunday's Los Angeles Times reports that according to a recently released man, Iraqi prisons have been the site of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of executions of political prisoners and common criminals in the latter part of 1997.

But the paper delays explaining the logic until the story's 15th paragraph: The Saudis are afraid that a mere air campaign will leave behind a Hussein vengeful towards Gulf neighbors that supported it.

The piece convinces the reader that Tucker's pickax is not an anomaly: "Among the ways condemned women have killed in this country are shooting with an AK-47, slicing with a box cutter, injecting with battery acid, and beating with a baseball bat.

The Post gives this order of battle: "F-117 stealth aircraft and A-10 fighter jets at Kuwait's Jabir Air Base, B-1 bombers and F-16 and F-15 fighter jets at Bahrain's Sheik Isa Airfield, F-14 and F-18 fighter jets on two carriers, cruise missiles on a number of other ships and B-52 bombers on the British island of Diego Garcia."

One drowned her paralyzed son by pushing him off a canoe on a family outing, leaving him and his 50 pounds of metal leg braces to sink to the bottom."
